quotes.text: I launched this podcast about six months ago. We've done exactly 50 episodes at this point. We've also done over 2 million downloads since we launched.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete milestone metrics that illustrate rapid output cadence and audience growth in a short time window.

quotes.text: The podcast is a top 10 technology podcast across Apple and Spotify globally.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific ranking example that signals strong distribution and category positioning across major platforms.

quotes.text: So what I decided to do with this final episode of the year is to look back at the 10 most popular episodes that we've done so far.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A simple year-end review methodology: use audience popularity to drive retrospectives and learning.

quotes.text: If it's not, we will never do it again. And if it is, awesome.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A lightweight experimentation mindset: try a new format, evaluate results, and either iterate or kill it.

quotes.text: So what I decided to do with this final episode of the year is to look back at the 10 most popular episodes that we've done so far.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Uses a simple, audience-driven selection criterion (popularity) to structure a year-end review.

quotes.text: So what I'm going to do is count down from the 10th most popular episode to number one and play a clip or two from that episode that I found to be most interesting or that's been the most popular.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Lays out a repeatable countdown methodology: rank items, then highlight representative clips based on interest and audience response.

quotes.text: I've never done this sort of episode before. We'll see how it goes. I think it's going to be really interesting. If it's not, we will never do it again. And if it is, awesome.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Models an experimentation mindset with a clear kill/keep decision rule based on outcomes.

quotes.text: Every week I interview some of my favorite thinkers to learn how we can bring out the best in ourselves and others.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grant
quotes.context: Highlights a consistent weekly practice (interviewing thinkers) as a method for extracting transferable lessons on performance and relationships.

quotes.text: I talk to defying rock climbers, Oscar-winning filmmakers, creators like Lin-Manuel Miranda, entrepreneurs like Mark Cuban and thought leaders like Brene Brown.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grant
quotes.context: Gives specific examples of cross-domain sourcing—pulling insights from diverse high performers rather than a single field.

quotes.text: Every week I interview some of my favorite thinkers to learn how we can bring out the best in ourselves and others.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grant
quotes.context: A repeatable learning method: regularly interview top thinkers with the explicit goal of extracting practices that improve performance and relationships.

quotes.text: I use Notion to coordinate this very podcast. Including my content calendar, my sponsors, and prepping guests for launch of each episode.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of operationalizing a single tool as the system of record for end-to-end podcast production workflows.

quotes.text: Notion is an all-in-one team collaboration tool that combines note-taking, document sharing, wikis, project management, and much more into one space that's simple, powerful and beautifully designed.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical “consolidate tools into one workspace” model for reducing fragmentation across collaboration, documentation, and execution.

quotes.text: And not only does it allow you to be more efficient in your work life, but you can easily transition to using it in your personal life, which is another feature that truly sets Notion apart.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a transferable workflow principle: use the same organizing system across work and personal projects to reduce switching costs.

quotes.text: The other day I started a home project and immediately opened up Notion to help me organize it all.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific behavioral cue (“immediately opened up”) that reinforces building a default habit of capturing and structuring new projects as they begin.

quotes.text: I actually think the first step in a good positioning exercise is to really understand what do we have to position against? So put another way, it's like saying, what do I have to beat in order to win a deal?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Defines positioning as a competitive exercise and sets the practical starting point: identify what you must beat to win.

quotes.text: But in B2B we kind of have two sets of competitors. We have status quo, which is whatever the company is doing to attempt to solve the problem right now, even if it's crappy and not great. And then there's, if the company does decide they're going to buy something different, they usually make a short list. So, it's whoever else lands on the short list.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Gives a concrete mental model for “competitive alternatives” that expands beyond direct competitors to status quo and shortlist rivals.

quotes.text: Now most folks will discount the status quo, but they shouldn't because in B2B we lose about 40% of our deals to, "No decision," which actually means we lost to the spreadsheet, we lost to pen and paper, we lost to interns.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder (with a data point and vivid examples) that the biggest competitor is often doing nothing.

quotes.text: So the easiest way to do this is, okay, this is what I have to position against, what have I got capabilities wise that the alternatives don't have?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Actionable method for generating differentiation: compare capabilities directly against identified alternatives.

quotes.text: And then the last piece of positioning of course is market category. And so again, a lot of people will just start with market category and then try to back up, which I think is crazy 'cause then we don't have any way to judge the goodness of a market category.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Challenges the common approach of starting with category, arguing you need differentiated value first to evaluate category fit.

quotes.topic_title: Why analytics efforts fail: measurement vs insight
quotes.text: Do not treat metric gathering as entertainment. It's not there for you to be like, oh, that's interesting, how novel, and then not act on it.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A sharp mental model: analytics only matters if it changes decisions and behavior, otherwise it’s just passive consumption.

quotes.topic_title: Why analytics efforts fail: measurement vs insight
quotes.text: So real news is information that changes what you do in the real world. And if you don't change what you're doing, what you are doing is just getting entertainment.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A practical test for whether a metric is useful: it should trigger an action, not just curiosity.

quotes.topic_title: Why analytics efforts fail: measurement vs insight
quotes.text: The next step in instrumentation is to look at the fact that measurements do not equate to insights.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A core framework distinction that helps teams stop mistaking raw observations for decision-ready insight.

quotes.topic_title: Why analytics efforts fail: measurement vs insight
quotes.text: The insight is instrumenting properties into an event so that you can segment who is doing what behavior and make some hypotheses on that observation, test that hypothesis and then you get some causal representation of whether or not that hypothesis was right.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for moving from tracking to learning: add context, segment, hypothesize, test, and validate causality.

quotes.topic_title: Why analytics efforts fail: measurement vs insight
quotes.text: An insight would be something like Goodfood users who are power users are more likely to use a free shipping discount on a high GMV basket versus non-power users.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A specific example of adding context (segment + condition) that directly informs targeting and spend decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Imposter syndrome as a growth signal
quotes.text: Being in an uncomfortable situation, being in a position where you feel like, hey, do I really know how to do this, I'm not prepared for it, kind of coincides with the fastest and most intense periods of growth in one's career.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhou
quotes.context: Reframes imposter feelings as a reliable signal that you’re in a high-growth stretch rather than failing.

quotes.topic_title: Imposter syndrome as a growth signal
quotes.text: Maybe if I constantly putting myself in this situation where I haven't seen this problem before, that's also what's going to push me to grow and learn.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhou
quotes.context: Encourages deliberately seeking novel, unfamiliar problems as a practical growth strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Imposter syndrome as a growth signal
quotes.text: And when you're at a company that grows, there's always a lot more opportunity to then be able to try something new, to raise their hand, to volunteer for things to be just thrown into because somebody has to do it because it's a growing company and there aren't a lot of other people.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhou
quotes.context: Gives a concrete career lever: choose fast-scaling environments to maximize scope and opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: Imposter syndrome as a growth signal
quotes.text: The second thing is embrace the fact that it's okay to be in a position where maybe you don't know what to do, you haven't been trained for.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhou
quotes.context: Normalizes being unprepared as part of the job, reducing hesitation to take on bigger roles.

quotes.topic_title: Imposter syndrome as a growth signal
quotes.text: Maybe approach it with that sense of curiosity and that sense of, yes, it's hard, yes, I might be an imposter and I might feel that way for a while, but this is also what's going to help me get there.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhou
quotes.context: Offers a practical mindset shift—curiosity over self-judgment—to persist through imposter syndrome while learning fast.

quotes.text: I think that so much of just exactly what you said, Lenny, I think so much of it that helped me was realizing that everyone feels this way to some extent.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhou
quotes.context: Normalizing imposter syndrome reduces shame and makes it easier to stay engaged through discomfort.

quotes.text: I mean, logically, let's think about it. If you're going to do anything new for the first time, how are you ever going to feel totally comfortable, totally prepared?
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhou
quotes.context: A simple mental model: discomfort is expected when doing something new, not evidence you don’t belong.

quotes.text: One is I am much better at asking for help now than I was earlier in my career.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhou
quotes.context: A concrete behavior change—ask for help earlier—to counter imposter-driven isolation.

quotes.text: Now I realize I was preventing myself from being able to get that support and that empathy and that camaraderie and that advice that would've helped me actually grow faster and maybe with a little bit less pain in the process.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhou
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: “faking it” can slow growth by cutting you off from the support that accelerates learning.

quotes.text: And then I think the third is it's also okay to just be vulnerable and just talk to people about.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhou
quotes.context: Using vulnerability as a collaboration tool helps teams share load and solve problems together.

quotes.text: Turns out these scientists, they kind of hate talking to people and they're kind of annoyed by all your questions. And so they've decided that they will answer only two of your questions and after that they expect a plan. What two questions do you ask?
quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.context: A practical interview constraint that forces candidates to prioritize and surface the few questions that unlock a viable plan.

quotes.text: And interestingly, all of a sudden, like the sharp product managers, engineers, basically every role, they very quickly find what are the two, one or two eigenquestions on this topic.
quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.context: Highlights the core mental model: strong thinkers rapidly identify the smallest set of high-leverage questions that drive decisions.

quotes.text: There's no right answer, but I'll tell you one of my favorite ones is as a product manager said, okay, if I had to ask two questions, the two questions I would ask, one is it safe enough for humans or not? And that was a very crisp way to get to just safety.
quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.context: A concrete example of an “eigenquestion” phrased to collapse complexity into a decision-driving binary.

quotes.text: Kids are incredibly good at simplifying these things down, it's actually a skill we remove from ourself.
quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that simplification is often unlearned over time—useful as a prompt to practice reduction to essentials.

quotes.text: I'll hear candidates tell me things, I guess I would ask them what size it is and why would you ask them what size? What decision is that going to allow you to make, to know what size?
quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for questioning: tie every question directly to a decision it enables, or discard it.

quotes.text: At some point you become a little more senior, we hand you a problem and you come back with the solutions and we judge you on the creativity and the effectiveness of the solutions.
quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.context: Clarifies the career progression shift from executing tasks to being evaluated on solution quality and creativity.

quotes.text: And at some point you're senior enough that you tell us the problems and you say, hey, I know you told me to go work on activation, but actually I think our issue is brand or I think our issue is quality or I think our issue is whatever it might be, and that's sort of the pinnacle of this way of thinking about it.
quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.context: Defines the highest-leverage senior behavior: reframing and redefining what the real problem is.

quotes.text: But in the middle the slope changes and all of a sudden it's not really about scope, it's about PSHE.
quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that mid-career evaluation shifts away from scope/size of work toward judgment and approach.

quotes.text: Everything about leading up to this moment from high school and college has been about scope. And at this point you're all of a sudden told, we're not judging you on scope anymore, we're judging you on this PSHE thing. That's very confusing.
quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.context: Explains why the mid-career transition feels disorienting: the success metric changes from scope to PSHE capabilities.

quotes.text: You go ask the sales team, who's the best salesperson and what you'll realize, and they'll say, quota statement is just a signal for how good you negotiate your quota and pick the right territory.
quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.context: Challenges the common practice of ranking salespeople by quota attainment by pointing out it can reflect territory/quota negotiation rather than skill.

quotes.topic_title: Behavioral science: the three Bs model
quotes.text: In order to change behavior, you have to pick a behavior that you want to change. So companies are really good at outcomes, but just not as sharp at picking the behavior.
quotes.speaker: Kristen Berman
quotes.context: Clarifies a common failure mode: teams optimize for outcomes without specifying the concrete user action to change.

quotes.topic_title: Behavioral science: the three Bs model
quotes.text: And when I say behavior, I mean action. The thing that you want someone to do, by the way, the only wrong answer here is log in. So it's really, it's not about logging in, it's about what you do after you log in.
quotes.speaker: Kristen Berman
quotes.context: Pushes practitioners to avoid vague metrics and define the real behavioral target beyond surface-level engagement.

quotes.topic_title: Behavioral science: the three Bs model
quotes.text: So example, if I'm Peloton PM and I'm working on the app, I would say something like within 7 days of somebody starting the app they do 2, 10 minute workouts with two different instructors.
quotes.speaker: Kristen Berman
quotes.context: Provides a concrete template for making behavior goals “uncomfortably specific” so they can be designed and measured.

quotes.topic_title: Behavioral science: the three Bs model
quotes.text: So the cognitive barriers get in our way as well. These are things like uncertainty aversion, this is optimism bias, information aversion. Status quo, big one.
quotes.speaker: Kristen Berman
quotes.context: Expands “barriers” beyond UX friction to include predictable cognitive biases that block adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Behavioral science: the three Bs model
quotes.text: So we are all present bias, which means we prioritize our present self over our future self. So there are plenty of reasons that somebody, your customer, your user should take an action, but you actually have to give them a reason to take an action today.
quotes.speaker: Kristen Berman
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for product design: emphasize immediate benefits to overcome present bias and drive action now.

quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold. If you don't have a SOC 2, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights SOC 2 as a gating factor for enterprise sales and partnership opportunities.

quotes.text: Beginning a SOC 2 report can be a huge burden, especially for startups. It's time consuming, tedious and expensive.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames the practical cost/effort reality of compliance work so teams can plan resourcing and timelines.

quotes.text: Over 3000 fast growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption and efficiency data point to benchmark automation potential.

quotes.text: Vanta can get you ready for security audits in weeks instead of months, less than a third of the time that it usually takes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives a specific time-to-audit improvement claim that can inform compliance planning and tool evaluation.

quotes.text: The only way that you will ever have any chance of acquisition being product led is if you nail your product led retention.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A clear sequencing rule: retention is the prerequisite for any product-led acquisition strategy to work.

quotes.text: Retention falls into two main KPIs, which is activation and then engagement.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A simple framework for operationalizing retention into two measurable components teams can own and improve.

quotes.text: So never start with product led acquisition. You first always have to start with product led retention, activation, and engagement.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable advice that flips the common growth playbook by prioritizing habit formation before scaling acquisition loops.

quotes.text: Then you can choose, is your product has a relationship of one to many? If it has a collaboration at its core, say Slack or Miro or even the Amplitude. Or does it have more of a single mode relationship? So let's say Snowflake, there is not one to many relationships there between users.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A diagnostic mental model (one-to-many vs single-mode) with concrete examples to decide whether product-led acquisition is feasible.

quotes.text: So even if you don't have that product like sales or self-serve in your industry now, I guarantee you it will pop up in the next 10 years. And if you are not going to introduce it, you will get disrupted by it.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A forward-looking warning that self-serve/product-led monetization is an inevitable shift practitioners should proactively prepare for.

quotes.topic_title: Freemium strategy: what to make free
quotes.text: So I mean you first have to align on what your strategic value of free is.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Sets the prerequisite that freemium decisions should start from the purpose of “free,” not feature-by-feature debates.

quotes.topic_title: Freemium strategy: what to make free
quotes.text: I do have a general framework of saying freemium has to check one of these boxes.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Introduces a clear mental model for deciding what belongs in the free tier.

quotes.topic_title: Freemium strategy: what to make free
quotes.text: So anything that actually creates friction for my growth model, I'll probably gate it in the paid. Anything that promotes my growth model, I will put it into free.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Provides an actionable rule-of-thumb for packaging free vs. paid around growth drivers and monetization friction.

quotes.topic_title: Freemium strategy: what to make free
quotes.text: Now it is very heavily dependent on your actual monetization strategies.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Highlights that freemium packaging must be tailored to how you plan to make money, not copied from other products.

quotes.topic_title: Freemium strategy: what to make free
quotes.text: How does free help me achieve my growth model outcomes without sacrificing monetization potential?
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Captures the core decision question that balances growth benefits of free with revenue constraints.

quotes.text: I think people under resource SEO a lot of times and over resource ads.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A contrarian framing that challenges default budget allocation and prompts teams to rebalance growth investment toward SEO.

quotes.text: There's two big things. The first thing is the addressable market large, SO'S the addressable market for SEO large? And for most categories it is. The second is, do you have authority, you have existing traction?
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A simple two-factor readiness framework for deciding whether SEO can be a meaningful growth lever.

quotes.text: So the way that we assess that is, the first signal I'll look at is what's your traffic? What's your current traffic? And your non SEO traffic is actually an authority signal. So I'll go into SimilarWeb, I'll put the domain in, I'll look at the total traffic and I'll want to see at least I would say 1,000 visits a day roughly for non SEO at least, if you have five visits that that's very little.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A concrete, tool-based benchmark practitioners can use to gauge whether they have enough baseline authority to make SEO viable.

quotes.text: And then the second thing I'll look at is the number of referring domains. So I'll go into Ahrefs or Semrush and look up the total number of referring domains. I'll try to have at least 1,000 roughly referring domains. You could grow with less than that and less than 1,000 visits, but it's much harder. And the more you have, the easier it is to grow and the faster you can grow and the more you can grow.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: An operational metric and threshold for SEO readiness that clarifies why early-stage sites often struggle to rank.

quotes.text: The one other thing I'll mention is that there are product competitors and audience competitors.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for sizing SEO opportunity by looking beyond direct competitors to whoever captures the same audience via search.

quotes.topic_title: LNO framework: leverage vs neutral vs overhead tasks
quotes.text: And then things changed when I discovered the ideas related to this LNO framework in a blog post. Unfortunately I can't even find that blog post somewhere, but it had some ideas that I took and then kind of created this LNO framework on myself, which is essentially that as a product manager or as anybody in a creative high impact, high leverage role, all your tasks are not created equal. There are actually three type of tasks that you end up doing in such a role.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Introduces the core mental model: explicitly categorizing work because not all tasks deserve equal effort.

quotes.topic_title: LNO framework: leverage vs neutral vs overhead tasks
quotes.text: So there are L tasks, which are leverage tasks. And the L tasks are such that when you put in a certain amount of effort, you get 10X or 100X in return in terms of impact. So those are L tasks, leverage tasks. Then there are neutral tasks, so that's N. And those are tasks where you basically get what you put in or just a little more than that. So you put in 1X and you get 1.1X. Those are neutral tasks. And then there are overhead tasks where you get back, again in terms of impact, you get back a lot less than you actually put in.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Defines the L/N/O categories with concrete return-on-effort ratios practitioners can use to triage their to-do lists.

quotes.topic_title: LNO framework: leverage vs neutral vs overhead tasks
quotes.text: And it turns out that many people, people who are ambitious or are perfectionists like myself, they by default treat each of these types of tasks the same way and therein lies the problem.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Highlights the common failure mode: applying the same level of rigor to everything creates stress and low impact.

quotes.topic_title: LNO framework: leverage vs neutral vs overhead tasks
quotes.text: What I realized that is that among the things in my to-do list, there are actually only very few L tasks. And so it made sense for me to focus a lot on those L tasks, to take on those L tasks when I was feeling most productive, most energetic during a certain time of the day. And, for the L tasks, let my inner perfectionist shine because I'm going to get so much more in return.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Actionable execution advice: reserve peak energy and high standards for the small set of truly high-leverage work.

quotes.topic_title: LNO framework: leverage vs neutral vs overhead tasks
quotes.text: And something I realized is that the same type of activity can actually be either an L task or an N task or an O task.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive nuance: you can’t label activities as inherently “high leverage”—the context determines the right level of effort.
